title: 109_s3559
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005". It addresses fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. The "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It outlines penalties for falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to disaster benefits. Anyone found making false statements or representations in connection with disaster benefits authorized under the Disaster Relief Act of 1974 may face fines, imprisonment for up to 30 years, or both. Anyone found making false statements or representations in connection with disaster benefits authorized under the Disaster Relief Act of 1974 may face fines, imprisonment for up to 30 years, or both. The circumstances include the benefit being in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce, transported in the mail, or being a record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value of the United States or any department or agency thereof. In this section, the term 'benefit' refers to any record, payment, money, or thing of value provided by the United States, State, or local government. SEC. 3 amends Section 1343 of title 18, United States Code, to increase criminal penalties for engaging in wire, radio, and television fraud in connection with benefits authorized during a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. SEC. 4 amends Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code to increase criminal penalties for engaging in mail fraud related to benefits during a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. The United States Sentencing Commission must increase penalties for fraud or theft related to disaster declarations and submit an explanation to Congress. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of offenses and the need for aggressive law enforcement action. It should also maintain consistency with other directives and guidelines. The Sentencing Commission must ensure guidelines reflect offense seriousness, need for law enforcement action, consistency with directives, account for circumstances justifying exceptions, make necessary changes, and meet sentencing purposes. The Commission must promptly issue guidelines or amendments within 30 days of the enactment of this Act, following the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987.
